parts: This framework requires you to provide three functions.
You can also import exceptions ServerError, ValidateError, FailPage and GoTo and raise them when required. Each is described below.

You can also optionally import the decorator function use_submit_list which, if used as a decorator around your submit_data function, will use the skicall.submit_list attribute to find an alternative function in your code.
There are some things you may expect of a Framework which Skipole does not provide:

parts.name: enablebackcolor
parts.brief: Checkbox form to enable background color in html tag

parts.name: setbackcolor
parts.brief: Form to set a background color in html tag

parts:
The background colour in the html tag can also be set by setting skicall.page_data['show_backcol'] to True  and skicall.page_data['backcol'] with the colour string such as '#FF0A00' to set the colour value.

If the option above is unticked and submitted, or skicall.page_data['show_backcol'] is set to False, then the background colour attribute will not be shown in the 'html' tag.

parts.brief: Paragraph about catch to HTML target
parts:
This Template page can be updated by a JSON call. If during such an update, a javascript error is thrown, and if a 'CatchToHTML' target label, or ident is set here - a call will be made and the page replaced. The target should be a Template page, or Responder leading to a Template page.

The CatchToHTML target can also be set by skicall.page_data['CatchToHTML'] being set to the label or ident.

parts.name: set_catch_to_html
parts.brief: Sets the target label or ident for javascript catch to HTML call

fields.label: Set the catch target ident or label:

input_text.message: An error widget must be provided

parts:
Once the template page is displayed on the client browser, you can optionally set it to request a JSON page at regular intervals. This is typically used to display status fields which need continual updating.
Input the refresh time in seconds, and the target label or ident number which, when called, should return a JSON file setting the required widgefields.

edit_template.brief: Page to edit a section placeholder
head: Part

head.brief: The head section of the page

body.brief: The body section of the page

parts: Note - alias names must consist only of characters A-Z, a-z, 0-9 and the underscore character, and should not clash with another section alias name or widget name on the same page.

fields.para_text: Warning - the section name has not been set on this placeholder.

parts.name: multiplier
parts.brief: Sets the multiplier on the section place holder

input_text.message: Invalid multiplier, should be between 0 and 9999

parts.name: mtag
parts.brief: Sets the multiplier container tag on the section place holder

parts:
A 'Section' will be inserted into the page with the given alias. Widget fields can then be set using a page_data key of (aliasname, widget name, field name).

Normally, a multiplier of 0 is set, which means the section will be simply inserted. However if the multiplier is given another value, say 3, then the section will appear three times, and the alias will have underscore and numbers attached, such as aliasname_0, aliasname_1 and aliasname_2.

This feature allows a section to be repeated down the page and populated entirely dependent on the data you wish to present.

If the multiplier is greater than zero, the list of sections will be held within a containing element. The tag of the container can be set here - typically a 'div'.

The multiplier can be set dynamically at run time with page_data[aliasname, 'multiplier'] = number, and the containing tag can be set with page_data[aliasname, 'multiplier_tag'] = value.

edit.brief: Sets data into the filepage edit page

template.brief: Displays the file page parameters and allows editing
head: Part

head.brief: The head section of the page

body.brief: The body section of the page

parts:
Calling the URL of this page from a browser will request the web server to get the file from the projectfiles location specified below, and download it to the client.  For performance reasons it is usually better to serve static files from a web server dedicated to the task rather than via this wsgi application, nevertheless, the capability is provided here should you wish to use it.
It is also possible - if the call is routed via a responder - for your submit_data function to set a different mimetype, filepath, or an iterator which can generate a file contents.
Please note: The filepath set here, or set by responder, should be relative to the projectfiles directory - so for a file called myfile in the static directory, the path should be myproject/static/myfile.

Note: This page has two fields 'filepath' and 'mimetype' which can be set via a responder, and so the file served by this page can be dynamically changed.

For unchanging static files, a header instruction to cache the file on the client browser can be sent by setting the option below to True. This will improve performance for images, javascript and css files. Do not set this option for files that are likely to change.

Since ident numbers must be unique in the project, you can add an integer to the ident number of the folder (and any content folders and pages) to take their idents outside the range of the current project ident numbers.

parts: The following settings do not alter your project.

These admin pages use CSS from the w3.css library. Your own project could use this or any other library - under the 'Page Labels' section, create labels to the CSS files of your choice, and within the 'Defaults' section, ensure they are included in each new page created.

If you do use another CSS library you will have to choose different widget CSS classes. When you add widgets with new CSS class fields, you can set your CSS classes to be defaults, and your project will be tailored to use your preferred CSS files.

Further information about w3.css can be found here:

parts.failmessage: failed to read textblocks database with ref index_test_colors

parts: The above automatically generates a colour palette. You can now fine tune it, by setting individual CSS colour strings.

head.brief: The head section of the page

body.brief: The body section of the page

parts:
Normally JSON pages have their content set dynamically, and you would simply use an empty JSON page such as 'general_json' and populate it using a responder to set page_data.
However, in some cases you may want some fields to be statically set - in which case you can add widgfields and values here.
Widgfields should be of the form widgetname,fieldname or sectionalias,widgetname,fieldname.

parts.name: addwidgfldform
parts.brief: Form to hold widgfield and value fields

parts:
The widgfield value can be either boolean True or False, or a text string.
Choose the value appropriate to the widget:

parts.name: jsontext
parts.brief: text area to set json widgfield text value

parts: For unchanging static pages, a header instruction to cache the page on the client browser can be sent by setting the option below to True. Do not set this option for pages that are likely to change.

parts:
When a section is added to a page, it is given an alias name unique within the page, this allows a section to be added multiple times within the page.

If the top tag is not given an id attribute here, it will automatically be given an id equal to the alias name. This is used by JSON calls when setting values to the section, so we strongly suggest you do not give the top tag an id.

head.brief: The head section of the page

body.brief: The body section of the page

parts:
The skis sub project is a part of the skipole framework and should always be added to your project.
It includes a number of pages - particularly javascript files used by widgets, and special pages such as the 'URL Not found' page.
For  example, your project will contain the special label 'url_not_found' which will point to 'skis,url_not_found'.
When your project returns a URL Not found message to a client, it calls this label which pulls in the page from the skis sub-project.
Similarly, when widgets are used in a page, and when the page is dynamically created, special javascript files will be inserted into the page head. Again these come from the skis sub project and are defined by their labels (which can be seen under the left navigation 'Page Labels' button).

The skis sub-project also includes a number of convenient TextBlocks.  These contain snippits of SVG code, which could be included within your own svg elements - such as within an svgbasics.TextBlockGroup widget to provide an icon.
Please note: To provide the full icon image the TextBlock needs to appear within an <svg> element, and also possibly a <g> tag with a transform attribute to scale the item. 

These icon TextBlocks are listed below:

Reference: svgicon.alarm
Width 100 height 100, this example is set into a group
with transform attribute "scale(0.5,0.5)".

Reference: svgicon.cross
Width 100 height 100, this example is set into a group
with transform attribute "scale(0.5,0.5)".

Reference: svgicon.home
Width 100 height 100, this example is set into a group
with transform attribute "scale(0.5,0.5)".

Reference: svgicon.left
Width 100 height 100, this example is set into a group
with transform attribute "scale(0.5,0.5)".

Reference: svgicon.logo
Width 256 height 128, this example is set into a group
with transform attribute "scale(0.25,0.25)".

Reference: svgicon.right
Width 100 height 100, this example is set into a group
with transform attribute "scale(0.5,0.5)".

Reference: svgicon.tick
Width 100 height 100, this example is set into a group
with transform attribute "scale(0.5,0.5)".
